column4: description
column9: Comments (your thoughts about what's interesting about the dataset... this is optional and only include if you might be interested in exploring the dataset further)
column14: MD4SG-related papers (to crowdsource within the MD4SG community)

column2: Survey of Income and Program Participation (SIPP)
column4: Household-based, longitudinal survey featuring a representative sample of households in the US interviewed, each of which are interviewed over a period of 2.5-4 years. The dataset includes information about income and government assistance programs to gain insight into the economic well-being of households and their changes over time.

column2: American Community Survey (ACS) Uniform Data Extracts
column4: A survey of a sample of households by the U.S. Census Bureau including demographic, housing, social, and economic information. This link is to a partial extract of the ACS.

A survey of renters in Milwaukee Area designed to collect new data on housing, poverty, and urban life. To survery renters in a private market is to focus on the experience of most low-income families living in cities, since low-income households are mostly excluded from both public housing and homeownership.

IPUMS CPS harmonizes microdata from the monthly U.S. labor force survey, the Current Population Survey (CPS), covering the period 1962 to the present. Data include demographic information, rich employment data, program participation and supplemental data on topics such as fertility, tobacco use, volunteer activities, voter registration, computer and internet use, food security, and more.
An annual dataset from 1960-2000 containing labor-market institutions and outcomes for 20 OECD countries (mostly from NA, EU, Oceania).
column9: Unsure who org collecting data would be

column4: Household survey providing a comprehensive look at quantitative measures of children, adults, and their children. This survey focuses on the state level (though the scope is national) with an emphasis on low-income families. Responses from more than 40,000 families.

The longest running longitudinal household survey, with a sample of over 18,000 individuals from 5,000 families. Information is collected continuously on both the individuals and their descendants. Data covers employment, income, education, amongst many others.

column2: Fragile Families and Child Wellbeing Study
column4: A study consisting of six waves of surveys, from 1998 to 2017, following 'focal children' which were born between 1998 and 2000. Data collected varies depending on the wave in question, but is comprehensive and tries to be as relevant to the developmental cycle of the focus children.

The NLSY79 is a nationally representative sample of 12,686 young men and women who were 14-22 years old when they were first surveyed in 1979. These individuals were interviewed annually through 1994 and are currently interviewed on a biennial basis.

This study consists of four completed publicly available surveys which take different approaches to the study's focus on adolescent health. A fifth wave of data collection is being collected and is available via restricted-use contracts.
column7: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

column4: A comprehensive set of epidemiological data regarding mental disorders for the general population, with a focus on minority groups.
column7: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research

column4: Statistical information on major Food and Nutrition Service Programs (FNS). These include the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP); the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants and Children (WIC); Child Nutrition Programs (National School Lunch, School Breakfast, Child and Adult Care, Summer Food Service and Special Milk); and Food Distribution Programs (Schools, Emergency Food Assistance, Indian Reservations, Commodity Supplemental, Nutrition for the Elderly, and Charitable Institutions).
Assortment of public datasets exploring social mobility and a variety of other outcomes in relation to geography, education, income, etc.
Very large quantity of datasets having to do with income inequality in a very large variety of countries worldwide, including both developed and developing nations.
column9: Thibault: Uncertain what org is running this

column4: Datasets which provide information about people who live in developing countries, their institutions, their environment, and their economy's operation. Most of these are owned by the Wolrld Bank and are free to use, but a handful of these datasets contain data whose use may be limited since owned by other agencies.
column8: it would be good to identify specific datasets from this that would be good to separately point out in addition to having the entire microdata library listed

column4: A large collection of datasets which provide global development data. Easily navigable by country and indicators, as well as by data type (time series, microdata, geospatial).

column2: US Census Data for Social, Economic, and Health Research
column4: Data collected from U.S. census microdata which is preserved and harmonized for easier analysis. Datasets include decennial censuses from 1790 to 2010, and American Community Surveys from 2000 to the present.
This collection of datasets is easily navigable by geography, and provides data pertaining to education, housing, income, demographics, and many more.
Datasets on a variety of topics from agriculture to finance to maritime information. Easily searcheable and navigable by topic.
column7: U.S. General Services Administration, Technology Transformation Service

column2: US Government Web Services and XML Data Sources
column4: An index to datasets from the US government's 3 branches and other entities (???). Navigable by branch, agency, board, corporation.

column2: Social Explorer demographic data and statistics
column4: Datasets on a variety of topics from agriculture to finance to maritime information. Easily searcheable and navigable by topic.
column9: Not sure that Social Explorer is truly the organization to credit for data collection

column4: Data extract from the 1994 US Census, with demographic and income labels, amongst some others.

column2: The Dartmouth Atlas of Health Care
column4: An array of geographical healthcare related data; Spending and utilization.
Data related to how Americans think and feel about various political issues/topics.

Nationally representative surveys focusing on health and demographics in developing countries. Types of surveys available are: Demographic and Health Surveys, Service Provision Assessment, HIV/AIDS Indicator Survey, Malaria Indicator Survey.

column2: IPUMS International census Data for Social Science and Health Research
column4: Data from 365 censuses collected from 96 countries.

column1: http://www.researchictafrica.net/home.php?h=199 Research ICT Africa Household and Business Surveys
column2: Research ICT Africa Household and Business Surveys
column4: business and household survey data about technology access and use, access to capital and financing

column2: South African and other African survey
column4: Survey and administrative microdata for South Africa and other African countries. A lot of public data, though there is some secure data that must be applied in order to access and use.
Triennial survey of US families which collects information on balance sheets, pensions, income, and demographic characteristics. No other study collects such information for the US.
column7: NORC at the University of Chicago

column2: Trends in income inequality over time
column4: Data on economic inequality in 25 countries (mostly developed). Significant indicators include earnings dispersion, overall income inequality, poverty, top income shares, wealth inequality.
column9: Not sure who to credit for data collection

column3: housing, transportation, bias and discrimination, demographics
column4: Data for perceived safety of 551952 locations in the US. Computer vision and machine learning was used to train algorithms using manually scored images to 'learn' how to perceive safety.
column7: Macro Connections group, Camera Culture group at MIT Media Lab

column4: Datasets (by state) containing information on police stops of cars. Notable indicators include stop location driver race/gender/age, stop reading, seach type, stop outcome, amongst others.

I'm not sure whether to include this one. Incredibly interesting, but it seems like the amount of data that is available is actually that useful. Check out https://www.crisistextline.org/open-data-collaborations

column2: National Cancer Institute: Surveillance, Epidemiology, and End Results Program
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention: Youth Risk Behavior Surveillance System
column4: Datasets with the purpose of monitoring health-related behaviors that are principal contributors to death and disability among youth and adults. Such indicators include behaviors that contribute to unintentional injuries and violence, sexual behavior, alcohol/drug use, tobacco use, unhealthy dietary behaviors, inadequate physical activity.

column3: Not sure whether there is any accessible data of interest

column2: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration
column4: Data from the National Survey on Drug Use and Health to which access is restricted. Topics of priority include serious mental illness, serious emotional disturbance, and opioids.

Data on education courtesy of the National Center for Education Statistics. Dataset topics include commeon education data standards, measurements of enrollment and attainment, and general educations statistics.
Very navigable database of US education data ranging. Labels include attendence/enrollment, meployment, finances, special education, student characteristics, among many others.
Database of health data which can be navigated by theme (topic), category, indicator, country.
Dataset containing correlations in google searches with searches for 'health'. Correlations are specified by state.

column2: Big Data for Social Good Challenge
column4: Suggested datasets for a data analysis challenge on the topic of improving social good. Examples of datasets include: red lights violation and crime rate, Department of homeless service and unemployment, among many more.

column3: Not sure how to report this one, isn't this more of an article than data?

column4: Data that is relevant to the National Bureau of Economic Research's interests from the economy in Africa and China to the importance of immigration in innovation.
Database of medicare health data which provides data on hospitals, physicians, inpatient care, suppliers, among many more.
column7: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

column4: Not sure how any data would be accessed

Data with information on participants of the AirBnB rental market. The dataset is used in this example to discern how discrimination does exist against African-Americans in this less regulated market.

column2: The Long-Term Trend and Main National Assessment of Educational Progress studies
column4: Database with results from the National Assessment of Educational Progress, which has monitored students' performance in math and readings in long term trend assessments since the 1970's. Data is navigable by subject, grade, jurisdiction and can be representative of state or district performance.

Database containing data that the Pew Research Center has released for public use. The topics of these datasets cover many topics, such as: U.S. politics and policy, religion and public life, internet and tech, global attitudes and trends

column2: Network Survival Method for Estimating Adult Mortality: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Rwanda
column4: This file contains the replication code and instructions for downloading the replication data from the Demographic and Health Surveys website.

column2: National Social Life, Health, and Aging Project (NSHAP)
column4: A study consisting of three waves of surveys that aim to understand the health of older adults (approx ages 57 to 85). Data collected tends to revolve around physical health and illness, medication use, cognitive function, emotional health, sensory function, health behaviors, social connectedness, sexuality, and relationship quality.

column2: US Department of Education Public Data Listing
column4: Database of public, machine-readable education data. On top of normal education-style datasets, includes some varied ones such as expulsions for firearm posession, civil rights data in regards to education, library data, etc.

column2: Linked Data for the Learning Analytics and Educational data Mining Community
column4: Database of education data across the world. Includes education data for Italy, UK, and online learning platforms.
Individual-level data on students from two Portuguese (secondary) schools. Includes student characteristics and academic achievement data.
Community-built database of education data, hosted by CMU. Includes data from both traditional and online education environments.
Data on how colleges serve their students. Indicators include: student completion, debt and repayment, earnings, among many more.
Data on early grade reading ability for developing countries. This data tends to be already curated in regards to the linguistic context of each study.
Education data consisting primarily of participant countries of the OECD. Data can be navigated either by indicators or as raw metric data.
column7: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development

column2: Armed Conflict Location and Event Data Project
column4: Data on political violence in Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. Labels include: date, country, actors involved, fatalities, etc.
column7: The Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project

column3: Not sure which dataset this was originally intended to point to

column4: Contains really well organized data sets, with and emphasis on networks. Very broad range of topics. Most datasets contain sets of nodes and edges. Excellent source.

column2: Datashop: a repository of learning interaction data
column3: I think this is a repeat of International Education Data Mining

column2: Stanford Network Analysis Project a network data repository
column4: A platform for network analysis and graph mining that easily scales to hundreds of millions of nodes. Network datasets are available for analysis, ranging from social networks to commercial networks to road networks.

column2: Kapsarc, over 1000 datasets mostly related to energy and the environment
column4: Data for Saudi Arabia, GCC, India, China and East Africa. Database focusing on energy supply (coal, nuclear, electricity, renewable energies, etc) and energy use (transportation, industry, agriculture, residential). Also contains datasets on miscellaneous categories.

column2: Kaggle Data Science for Good challenge
column4: 14,000 datasets from Kaggle users. Easily searchable by size, file format, license, etc.
Database of over 2600 open data portals from around the world. A more legible list of portals sorted by country is accessible on the OpenDataSoft website link on the page.

US data on a range of topics. Contains a lot of micro and macro sets. The set also has a lot of text and data visualizations with each dataset. There is an API that allows you to gain access to this dataset.
Economics and population statistics of Africa
Large database of general data collected in the Kenya region.
Large database of general data collected in the Uganda region.
Large database of general data collected in the Ethiopia region.
Large database of general data collected in British Columbia.
Large database of data collected in the UK.

column2: Open Data for the Dublin region
column4: Database of open data for the Dublin Region.

column2: Open Data portals for various cities in the US including:
column4: Census data for US cities. 1129 datasets in 129 different places.
Seattle oriented dataset. Public city-generated data.

Database of public, city-generated data for San Francisco. Categories of datasets include economy and community, transportation, public safety, health and social services, housings and buildings, amongst many more.
Database of public, city-generated data for Austin, Texas. Categories of datasets include: transportation, health, neighborhoods, public safety.

Database of public, city-generated data for Chicago, Illinois. Categories of datasets include: buildings, education, environment, ethics, historic preservation, sanitation, transportation, public safety, among many more.

Database of public, city-generated data for New York City, NY. Categories of datasets include: business, city government, education, environment, health. Easily navigable by popularity, recency, and agency that collected data.

Database of public, city-generated data for Boston, Massachusetts. Categories of datasets include: geospatial, city services, permitting, finance, environment, economy, public safety, facitilies, etc.

column2: Analyzing Public Opinion of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program:
column4: Research paper addressing machine learning analysis of drug overdosage trends. Focuses on data collected in the New York City, and Allegheny County area.

column2: Data for community advocacy in urban renewal:
column4: Research paper addressing the use of data science as a community advocacy tool to promote equity in urban renewal programs. An analysis of Atlanta's Anti-Displacement Tax Fund.
column7: University of Tennessee, Duke University, Spelman College, Georgia State University, Stony Brook University, Georgia Institute of Technology, HELP Organization Incorporate

column4: Research paper addressing the divide in incarceration trends between rural and urban incarceration rates. Focuses on county level demographic differences.
column7: Two Sigma Data Clinic, Vera Institute of Justice

column2: Equity in 311 Reporting: Understanding Socio-Spatial Differentials in the Propensity to Complain
column3: bias and descimination, deomographics, civic participation
column4: Research paper focusing on understanding Socio-Spatial Differentials in the Propensity to Complain. Looking at socio-economic and demographic characteristics of an area, cultural differences that can affect citizens' willingness to interact with their government, and differential access to Internet connectivity.

column2: Data science for urban equity: Making gentrification an accessible topic for data scientists, policymakers, and the community
column4: Research paper on making gentrification and accessible topic for policymakers and data scientists. Mainly focusing on gentrification in the Seattle area.

A Multi-Scale Analysis of 27,000 Urban Street Networks: Every US City, Town, Urbanized Area, and Zillow Neighborhood
column4: Research paper analyizing urban street networks in every US city.

column2: Sweden health willingness-to-pay for tick-borne disease vaccine
column4: The study estimates the willingness to pay (WTP) for TBE vaccination and the effect of a possible TBE vaccine subsidy on vaccination rates in Sweden. We also estimate the current vaccination coverage in areas differing in TBE incidence and analyze the role of income, risk behavior and other factors influencing vaccine demand.

The Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab (J-PAL) is a global research center working to reduce poverty by ensuring that policy is informed by scientific evidence. Anchored by a network of 171 affiliated professors at universities around the world, J-PAL conducts randomized impact evaluations to answer critical questions in the fight against poverty.
Focuses on the impact of diarrhea diseases in Kenya, and how to go about creating ways to ensure clean water supplies.
column9: Recently used by Yusuke Narita for Towards an Ethical Experiment https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3094905

column2: MIMIC-III Critical Care database (electronic health records)
column4: MIMIC is a relational database containing tables of data relating to patients who stayed within the intensive care units at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center.
Focuses on the academic progress of highschoolers in Tennessee. This research is attempting to guage the effectiveness of different class configurations.
Contains data relating to organ procurement and transportation. Contains both national and regional datasets.
column7: US Department of Human Health Services

column4: Database of data products of the Boston Area Research Initiative. There is both a library of datasets as well as an interactive map which helps visualize all the data that BARI has collected.

column2: Moving to Opportunity for Fair Housing
column4: longitudinal; seminal RCT randomizing high-poverty households with housing vouchers to move to wealthier neighborhoods.
Data releases on mortgage loans, defaults (most recent data release should also include race information)
Requestable data from NIH via the BioLINCC System (e.g. including clinical trials)
column7: National Heart Lung and Blood Institute

column4: Data quantifying the influence of policy outputs or political, social, or economic factors on policy making in different states. Variables include: policy outputs, criminal justice, demographics, economic and fiscal, education, election, energy/improvement, health, etc.
Very expansize github repo. The README provides a table of contents. Everything is public.
A database of artificial medical patients. The database is also costumizable, and can be configured based on parameters. A very powerful research tool.
